name: Stream Control Transmission Protocol
summary: A transport layer protocol in the Internet protocol suite that provides reliable, connection-oriented, and message-oriented communication. It is designed to transport Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN) signaling messages over IP networks, but is also used for other applications requiring reliable message delivery.
purpose: Provide reliable, message-oriented transport with multiple streams, multi-homing support, and protection against head-of-line blocking

handshake.description: SCTP uses a 4-way handshake to establish an association between endpoints, providing protection against SYN flooding attacks.
steps: Step 1 (INIT): Initiating endpoint sends an INIT chunk to the peer to start association.
Step 2 (INIT-ACK): Receiving endpoint responds with an INIT-ACK chunk.
Step 3 (COOKIE-ECHO): Initiator sends a COOKIE-ECHO chunk to verify receipt of INIT-ACK.
Step 4 (COOKIE-ACK): Responder sends COOKIE-ACK to confirm the association is established.

fields.name: Verification Tag
fields.description: Used to verify that incoming packets belong to the correct SCTP association

fields.name: Checksum
fields.description: CRC32c checksum for header and payload integrity

structure.header: Source Port, Destination Port, Verification Tag, Checksum
structure.payload: SCTP chunks containing data or control information

usage: Transport of telecommunication signaling messages over IP networks
Applications requiring reliable, ordered delivery of messages over multiple streams
Redundant multi-homed connections for failover scenarios
pitfalls: Higher overhead compared to TCP due to multi-stream and multi-homing support
Less widely supported in operating systems and network devices than TCP/UDP
No built-in encryption; requires additional layers (e.g., DTLS) for security
